description.narrative: In cocoa, IDH focuses on prototyping innovative field-level projects that make cocoa farming a sustainable business for the farmer, and cocoa supply more secure for the industry. Our neutral positioning as a convenor and knowledge broker, allows us to take risks in testing and developing innovative projects to generate insights that benefit the entire cocoa supply chain. The IDH Cocoa program works on initiatives that aim to improve the livelihoods of cocoa farmers and elevate them from poverty to middle class, while simultaneously ensuring a secure and sustainable supply of fair and high quality cocoa for the global market. Learning and best practice from field level projects is fed back into the industry as a whole in order to improve and join-up existing supply chain initiatives. Three areas of innovation are focused on through the program: Productivity – by building capacity at the farmer level through relevant and accessible training initiatives that improve efficiency and ‘bankability’; Community – gender empowerment and curbing malnutrition in cocoa communites; Environment – sustainable land use and zero net deforestation in the wider Taï Forest region. By working to improve the productivity of cocoa farmers and address fundamental issues around gender discrimination, malnutrition and ecological degradation, a more secure and steady supply of high-quality and sustainable cocoa can be guaranteed for the global market.

The program expenditure refers to: the payables to Implementing Partners for program implementation costs (IDH enters multi-year agreements with private and other implementing partners to execute the implementation of program activities in the field) and the IDH internal expenditures in the program development. Due to confidential agreements with some of the implementing partners, IDH reserves the right to publish organizations names, data and other relevant information. Aggregated results will be published on an aggregated commodity/landscape program level.

comment.narrative: Farmer Field Book (FFB) adopted by Barry Callebaut and Ecom Ecom and Barry Callebaut have adopted the Farmer Field Book approach to data collection, which provides reliable sample-based performance data on yields, income, loyalty and diversification. Ecom trained 65 members of staff to visit 995 farmers on a bi-weekly basis, and has completed a one-year cycle of data collection. The insights derived from the methodology are used to better tailor its farm services to the business reality of the farmers. Consecutive years of data will enable the company to observe the results of its sustainability program. Barry Calleabaut is still in the process of collecting its first year’s data. In 2017, we will explore upscaling this by introducing it to new partners.

a) To gain better insights into the effect of the delivery of productivity packages (“services”) to farmers, IDH supported Barry Callebaut with implementation of the FFB amongst a sample of 255 farmers, located in 6 regions across the cocoa growing zone in Côte d’Ivoire. The first results showed that farmers who received a Productivity Package in 2015/16 had higher yields in the 2016/17 season. However, as the data on which the report is based is largely recall data, it warrants care when drawing conclusions. b) IDH also support Ecom out with Farmer Field Book approach to get a better understanding of the farm economics of the farmers. The data collection of 722 farmers spread out over 36 districts in 6 regions was used for the analysis. Data show that 30% of farmers have no other income sources apart from cocoa. 56% of farmers depend on cocoa for 80-100% of their total household income. All farmers derive at least 40% of their income from cocoa. This clearly shows that a focus on cocoa as a core crop is appropriate for interventions. On the farm economics, the data show that farmers who invest more also generally show higher productivity. Profit however is not necessarily higher with higher investment levels. Also, the data shows that the fertilizer cost (comprised of cost for fertilizer, compost and manure) is the largest cost item, while hired labor and biocides account for most of the remaining costs.
Main results in connection to the yield show that more intensive farm management (spraying, pruning, weeding etc.) has a significant influence on productivity, contrary to last year’s analysis, nutrient application levels do not show a significant correlation, but labor for fertilizing does.
